title: Day 1278
content:
# Day 1278

**The March Towards Abundance.**

I keep coming back to this one thought. **A Rolex and a Casio both tell time with surgical precision.** Your grandmother's $15 drugstore watch probably keeps better time than Napoleon's pocket chronometer ever did. A Rolls Royce and a Toyota Corolla will both deliver you safely from your morning coffee to your evening doom-scroll, likely while playing the same Spotify playlist through speakers that would make Mozart weep with joy.

So why does one cost as much as a small house while the other costs as much as... well, a really nice dinner?

The answer lies in scarcity, my dear reader, but not the kind you think.

**The Utility Delusion**

We tell ourselves we're paying for "quality" or "craftsmanship," but let's be honest: you're not buying a Rolex to tell time more accurately. You're buying 200 years of Swiss marketing wrapped around your wrist like a very expensive anxiety bracelet. The Toyota gets you to work just as excited to take on a new day as the Rolls Royce would. That doesn't stop most people, myself included, from wanting the nicer whip.

This is the dirty secret of capitalism: most of what we pay premium prices for isn't about function, it's about the theater of scarcity. Precious metals. Hand-assembled components. Limited production runs. The promise that somewhere, somehow, you're getting something that can't be easily replicated.

But what happens when AI decides to crash this particular party?

**Welcome to Superabundance**

Picture this: AI-powered manufacturing that operates 24/7, designing and producing goods with the relentless efficiency of a caffeinated intern who never sleeps. Vertical farms growing perfect tomatoes in repurposed shipping containers. 3D printers churning out everything from houses to haute couture.

When the marginal cost of producing almost anything approaches zero, traditional pricing models don't just break, they explode like a Nokia phone in a hydraulic press.

Your "luxury" watch? An AI could [design a superior version](https://x.com/ConorChepenik/status/1966889545443721224), manufacture it with recycled materials, and deliver it via drone before you finish reading your morning coffee. The only thing stopping this future is our collective agreement to pretend that scarcity still matters when it demonstrably doesn't.

**The Scarcity Shell Game**

In a world where physical goods become as abundant as digital files scarcity doesn't disappear, it relocates. Remember when you paid $20 for a CD? If you are younger than me you probably dont. The point is that like a cosmic game of musical chairs, value moves to whatever can't be copy-pasted into existence:

**Human attention** becomes the new oil. While AI can produce infinite content, it can't manufacture the 24 hours in your day or force you to care about something. Your focus becomes a precious, non-renewable resource that everyone wants to mine.

**Authentic experiences** become priceless. Anyone can own a perfect reproduction of the Mona Lisa, but only one person at a time can stand in front of the actual painting in the Louvre, surrounded by confused tourists trying to figure out why it's smaller than expected.

**Trust** becomes the ultimate luxury. When AI can generate convincing deepfakes of your grandmother selling cryptocurrency, being a verified, authentic human becomes a premium service. "Real Person Certification" might be the growth industry of 2030.

**The Honey Badger of Money**

Here's where things get deliciously weird. While we're all debating whether AI will destroy or save us, Bitcoin has been quietly rewriting the rules of value itself, like a financial honey badger that simply doesn't care about your economic theories.

Bitcoin represents something genuinely scarce in our increasingly abundant world: mathematically enforced digital scarcity. Twenty-one million coins, full stop. No AI can manufacture more, no government can print additional units, no Swiss watchmaker can handcraft a limited edition.

In a superabundant future where your refrigerator can probably manufacture a decent sandwich and your car changes its oil itself, or uses a different energy source all together, Bitcoin emerges as the ultimate store of value precisely because it's the one thing that can't be made abundant. It's scarcity as a feature, not a bug.

While central banks continue their time-honored tradition of printing fiat money like it's going out of style (which, ironically, it is), Bitcoin sits there like a stoic digital boulder, unchanging and unmoved by the chaos around it. It's the Rolex that actually deserves its premium, not because of craftsmanship or heritage, but because of mathematical inevitability.

**The Mass Production of Feelings And Why It Won't Work**

You can't mass-produce a feeling or a memory. Or can you?

Well, Disney has been trying for decades, and they're pretty good at it. Virtual reality is getting scary-good at manufacturing experiences. AI therapists might soon provide more consistent emotional support than your actual friends (who, let's face it, are often too busy with their own problems to properly validate yours).

But here's the thing: even if we can manufacture synthetic emotions and artificial memories, the knowledge that they're manufactured changes everything. It's like discovering that your favorite restaurant's "secret family recipe" came from a corporate test kitchen in New Jersey. The sauce tastes the same, but something ineffable is lost.

**The Social Capital Revolution**

When goods are abundant and experiences can be synthesized, the most valuable commodity becomes the one thing that can't be automated: genuine human connection.

Your ability to build relationships, to be trusted, to create communities, these become the new precious metals. Social capital transforms from a nice-to-have networking concept into the actual foundation of the economy.

The person who can bring people together, who can facilitate genuine connections, who can build and maintain communities, that person becomes incredibly valuable in a way that no amount of manufacturing efficiency can replicate.

**The Great Restructuring**

So yes, we probably do need to restructure capital markets from scratch. The current system is built on the assumption that scarcity is natural and persistent. When that assumption breaks, the whole edifice starts wobbling like a Jenga tower in an earthquake.

Bitcoin might be the first piece of this new financial architecture, a base layer of absolute scarcity upon which we can build new systems of value exchange. It's like starting with bedrock instead of sand.

But the real revolution won't be in the money itself, it'll be in what we choose to value. When everything is abundant, what we pay attention to, who we trust, and how we connect with each other become the true measures of wealth.

**The Punchline**

The ultimate irony? In our quest to make everything abundant, we might finally discover what was actually scarce all along: each other.

Your Rolex might become worthless, but your ability to make someone laugh, to offer genuine comfort, to build something meaningful with other humans is the one thing no AI can manufacture at scale.

And your Bitcoin? Well, that's just sitting there, being mathematically scarce, waiting for the rest of the economy to catch up to what it's always known: true value comes from what cannot be created at will.

The future isn't about having everything. It's about choosing, from infinite abundance, what actually matters. And that choice? That's still gloriously, stubbornly, beautifully human.

![Ain't No Second Best](https://miro.medium.com/1*iEyvs7a8Gvqh3naJa5rTxg.png)

9/20/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
